questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis is undergoing treatment with streptomycin. Which of the following is the primary intracellular site of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and the primary intracellular site of action of aminoglycosides is the 30S ribosomal subunit.

Mechanism of action of aminoglycosides: 

  • Aminoglycosides are transported actively across the cell membrane into the cytoplasm (oxygen-dependent process)
  • Binding of aminoglycosides to 30S ribosomes cause misreading of mRNA template and result in incorporation of incorrect amino acids in the growing polypeptide chain
  • The resulting aberrant proteins may be inserted into the cell membrane leading to altered permeability of the cell membrane of bacteria causing bacterial death (bactericidal)

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: Which of the following statements about aminoglycosides is false?

choices.text: They are excreted unchanged in urine

questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides are rapid bactericidal agents.

Aminoglycosides like streptomycin and tobramycin cause hearing loss in a newborn child when taken during pregnancy. They are polar compounds and are excreted usually unchanged in the urine. They are distributed mainly in the extracellular compartment.

Primarily bacteriostatic drugs are:

  • Sulfonamides
  • Erythromycin
  • Tetracyclines
  • Clindamycin
  • Chloramphenicol
  • Linezolid
  • Ethambutol

Primarily bactericidal drugs are:

  • Penicillins
  • Cephalosporins
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Vancomycin
  • Polypeptides
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Rifampin
  • Metronidazole
  • Isoniazid
  • Cotrimoxazole
  • Pyrazinamide

questions.text: A young man working in a rabbit farm presents with fever, lymphadenopathy and an ulcer on the hand and is diagnosed with tularemia. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Streptomycin (if not available, gentamicin) is considered the drug of choice for the treatment of tularemia.

Tularemia is caused by Francisella tularensis, an aerobic gram-negative bacteria.

questions.text: A child presented with recurrent episodes of cough with expectoration. Investigations revealed a positive sweat chloride test. Inhalational formulation of which of the following aminoglycosides is approved for use in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. Inhalational formulation of tobramycin is approved for use in cystic fibrosis patients with Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections.

Option A: Injectable formulation of amikacin is used in cystic fibrosis. 

Options B & D: Inhalational formulations of gentamicin and streptomycin are available but they are usually not used.

Note: The question is about approved inhalational formulation.

questions.text:
The organisms detected in culture and sensitivity reports of various specimens obtained from the patients from a medical ward are given below. In which of the following infections would amikacin not be indicated?
  1. Pus culture positive for Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  2. Sputum culture positive for Klebsiella pneumoniae
  3. Urine culture positive for Proteus mirabilis
  4. Blood culture positive for Serratia marcescens
  5. Urine culture positive for Enterococcus faecalis
questions.solution:
Amikacin has less activity against enterococci and hence is not indicated in infections caused by this organism. In enterococcal infections, gentamicin along with penicillin (or ampicillin) is given.

Amikacin is used against serious nosocomial gram-negative bacillary infections which are resistant to gentamicin and tobramycin. It has good activity against most strains of the following organisms:

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Serratia
  • Proteus
  • Klebsiella
  • Enterobacter 
  • Escherichia coli

questions.text: Oral neomycin will not be effective for treating which of the following patients?

choices.text: A patient requiring pre-operative antisepsis for bowel surgery
A elderly man with hepatic encephalopathy
A child with enteropathogenic E. coli associated diarrhea
A woman with a cut wound on the finger

questions.solution:
Topical neomycin is used widely for a variety of infections of the skin and mucous membranes and to prevent infection of minor cuts and wounds.

Oral neomycin can be used for the eradication of bacteria confined to GIT in the following conditions:

  • Pre-operative antisepsis for bowel surgery
  • Hepatic encephalopathy: To reduce deleterious ammonia producing bacteria
  • Enteropathogenic E. coli associated diarrhea

Orally administered neomycin is poorly absorbed from the GI tract and is eliminated unchanged in the feces.

Neomycin is highly nephrotoxic in human beings and hence should not be administered systemically.

questions.text: A patient with hospital-acquired pneumonia is being treated with an aminoglycoside antibiotic by a single daily dose administration method. This method is preferred over the multiple daily dosage method because of which of the following properties of aminoglycosides?
questions.solution:
Single daily dose aminoglycoside administration is more preferable to multiple daily dose administration because of the long post-antibiotic effect.

For certain classes of drugs such as aminoglycosides and quinolones, its antimicrobial action is dependent on the peak concentration above MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration). It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. 

High-dose, extended-interval dosing schemes take advantage of the concentration-dependent activity of aminoglycosides to achieve maximal initial bacterial killing. And then because of the postantibiotic effect of aminoglycosides, good therapeutic response can be attained even when concentrations fall below MIC for a substantial fraction of the dosing interval. 

Therefore, a single daily dose would be equal to or more effective than multiple 8 hourly doses. This dosing strategy may also reduce the ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity of these drugs.

Time-dependent killing is an effect seen when the antimicrobial action is dependent on the duration, the drug concentration remains above the MIC. Beta-lactams, macrolides, and vancomycin have this property.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with urinary tract infection receives a single intramuscular dose of gentamicin. Within how many minutes of administration is the peak concentration of this drug achieved?
questions.solution:
Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and the peak concentration of aminoglycosides following intramuscular administration is achieved after 30-90 minutes.

Aminoglycosides need therapeutic dose monitoring because of their low therapeutic index especially in patients in whom renal function is compromised. Both trough and peak levels are calculated for aminoglycosides.

questions.text: The urine culture and sensitivity report of a patient with urinary tract infection is positive for aminoglycoside-resistant Enterococcus faecalis. What is the most common mode of this resistance?

choices.text: Inhibition of transport across bacterial membranes
Drug efflux mechanism through the membrane

questions.solution:
Clinically, the most common cause of aminoglycoside resistance is drug inactivation by enzymes.

The inactivating enzymes are commonly acquired through conjugation and transfer of plasmids containing resistance genes.

Causes of aminoglycoside resistance are:

  • Drug inactivation by enzymes
  • Increased drug efflux
  • Decreased permeability to the drug
  • Modifications of the 30S ribosomal subunit that interferes with binding of the aminoglycosides

questions.text: In which of the following patients will you prescribe aminoglycosides at a lower dose?

choices.text: A urosepsis patient with associated AKI
A cystic fibrosis patient with acute pulmonary exacerbation
A  diabetic patient with infected burn wounds

questions.solution:
The dose of aminoglycosides is to be reduced in patients with renal failure (AKI) because clearance of the drug is reduced.

Aminoglycosides undergo minimum metabolism and are primarily excreted almost entirely by glomerular filtration. Therefore, renal failure decreases the clearance of the drug. Because the incidence of nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity is likely related to the overall exposure to aminoglycosides, it is critical to reduce the maintenance dose and dosing interval of these drugs in patients with impaired renal function.

Option B: Renal clearances are increased and the half-life is reduced in cystic fibrosis patients necessitating higher doses. 

Option C: Burn patients have a more rapid drug clearance probably due to increased drug loss through burnt tissue and require higher doses in them.

Option D: Aminoglycoside dose adjustment is not required in liver disease

questions.text: A patient who was on aminoglycoside therapy presents with nausea and vomiting. Investigations revealed rising serum creatinine levels, and granular casts were seen on urine microscopy. Which of the following aminoglycosides is least likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario depicts a case of aminoglycoside-induced nephrotoxicity and the least nephrotoxic among aminoglycosides is streptomycin because it does not concentrate in the renal cortex. 

Among aminoglycosides, neomycin has the highest and streptomycin has the least nephrotoxicity.

Adverse effects of aminoglycosides are:

  • Nephorotoxicity
  • Ototoxicity
  • Acute neuromuscular blockade and apnea
  • Hypersensitivity reactions (rare)

questions.text: Vestibular toxicity is predominantly seen with which of the following aminoglycosides?
questions.solution:
Vestibular toxicity is predominantly seen with streptomycin and gentamicin. 

Ototoxicity seen with aminoglycosides:

  • Cochlear toxicity (high-pitched tinnitus) - amikacin, kanamycin, neomycin 
  • Vestibular toxicity (moderately intense headache and vertigo) - streptomycin > gentamicin 
  • Both vestibular toxicity and cochlear toxicity - tobramycin

questions.text: A patient who was recently started on i.v. gentamicin for enterococcal endocarditis presented to the OPD with complaints of headache and dizziness. By which of the following mechanisms does the drug cause this adverse effect?

choices.text: Inhibition of hair cell Na+/K+ ATPase

questions.solution:
The scenario depicts a case of gentamicin-induced ototoxicity which is caused due to direct hair cell toxicity. Degeneration of vestibular hair cells and neurons leads to vertigo and associated headache.

Streptomycin and gentamicin produce predominantly vestibular effects. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin primarily affect auditory function. Tobramycin affects both equally.

questions.text: An elderly patient who was taken up for an emergency laparotomy showed prolonged respiratory depression which did not resolve with neostigmine.  On inquiry, the attendant confirmed that the patient was on aminoglycoside therapy. Which of the following is least likely to cause this effect?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts the neuromuscular blockade effect of aminoglycosides, and tobramycin has the least potency for blockade in this group.

Decreasing order of potency for the neuromuscular blockade is:

Neomycin > Kanamycin > Amikacin > Gentamicin > Tobramycin

It is a recognized clinical side effect of aminoglycoside antibiotics, and this effect becomes significant (prolonged respiratory depression) when the drug is used in conjunction with neuromuscular blocking agents or calcium channel blockers. They are avoided in patients with myasthenia gravis.

Aminoglycosides cause neuromuscular blockade by interfering with calcium channels and thereby inhibiting acetylcholine's pre-junctional release and post-junctional sensitivity. The neuromuscular blockade produced by these antibiotics is not reversed by neostigmine but is reversed by IV calcium gluconate.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is the drug of choice for scrub typhus.

Azithromycin, chloramphenicol, or rifampin can be administered as alternatives in patients allergic to doxycycline and in pregnancy.

questions.text: By which of the following mechanisms do tetracyclines inhibit protein synthesis?

choices.text: Inhibition of initiation of translation and misreading of mRNA
Binding to 30S subunit and inhibiting the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to A site
Binding to 30S subunit and inhibiting peptide  bond formation
Inhibits binding of aminoacyl-t-RNA to 50s subunit of ribosome

questions.solution:
Tetracyclines inhibit protein synthesis by binding to 30s subunit and inhibiting the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the A (acceptor) site of the mRNA – ribosome complex.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is resistant to tetracyclines?
questions.solution:
All strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are resistant to the action of tetracyclines.

Tetracyclines are active against MRSA and MSSA. Doxycycline and minocycline can be used in cutaneous MRSA infections.

Rickettsia and chlamydia are highly susceptible to tetracyclines. Tetracyclines are considered first line agents for chlamydial infections like non-specific urethritis/ endocervicitis and rickettsial infections like typhus, rocky mountain spotted fever, Q fever.

They are also second-line drugs in patients with syphilis who are allergic to penicillin.

Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic drugs which are more active against gram-positive than gram-negative. They are effective against spirochetes, Haemophilus ducreyi, Vibrio cholera, Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions is doxycycline not used?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is not used in typhoid infection. Enterobacteriaceae and gram-negative anaerobes are resistant to tetracyclines, hence doxycycline is not used in intraabdominal infections. Third-generation cephalosporins and quinolones are used in treating typhoid fever.

Doxycycline treatment for 21 days is the first-line therapy for lymphogranuloma venereum. It is also indicated as one of the first-line treatments for borreliosis. 

Doxycycline is the alternative to penicillin for the treatment of leptospirosis.

questions.text: Tetracycline is used for the prophylaxis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Tetracycline is used for the prophylaxis of cholera. It is recommended for close contacts of a case of cholera. It is supposed to be effective in preventing spread.

Doxycycline in combination with rifampicin is used for prophylaxis of brucellosis. It is also used in the prophylaxis of leptospirosis.

Note: The question is about the drug tetracycline and not about the class of tetracyclines as a whole.

questions.text: The urine culture and sensitivity report of a patient is positive for tetracycline-resistant Enterococcus faecalis. Which among the following is a minocycline derivative that can be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
Tigecycline is a glycylcycline and a derivative of minocycline that is active against most bacteria that are resistant to classical tetracyclines, and hence can be used in this condition.

The mechanism of action is similar to tetracyclines. It is used against enterobacteriaceae, gram-negative anaerobes, and enterococcus which are resistant to tetracyclines.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone is prescribed a drug known to cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Identify this drug.
questions.solution: The drug described here is demeclocycline. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is associated with the use of this drug. This side effect of the drug is utilized in the treatment of SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone).

questions.text: A patient develops dizziness, ataxia, and nausea after he was started on an antimicrobial drug. Which of the following drugs can be implicated?
questions.solution:
The drug described here is minocycline as it is associated with vestibular toxicity which manifests as dizziness, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. Symptoms usually occur soon after the initial dose is given and disappears 24-48 hours after drug administration is stopped.

Uses of minocycline are:

  • Cutaneous MRSA infections
  • Along with sulfonamides for nocardiosis (alternative therapy)
  • Subgingival administration in dentistry (extended-release preparations)

questions.text: An infant on antibiotics becomes very irritable. Investigations reveal increased intracranial pressure. However, the condition resolves on discontinuation of the drug. Which drug had the baby likely been on?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts a case of pseudotumor cerebri and tetracyclines are associated with this condition in infants, even when given in normal doses. Only elevated intracranial pressure is seen without any abnormality in the spinal fluid. Increased pressure returns to normal after therapy is discontinued.

Other side effects of tetracyclines are:

  • Teratogenic
  • Deposit in developing teeth and bones, cause brownish discoloration of teeth (chelating property)
  • Marked suppression of normal flora of intestine causing superinfection. Pseudomembranous enterocolitis is a rare side effect

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not require dose reduction in patients with renal failure?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline does not require dose reduction in renal failure. Doxycycline, minocycline, and glycylcyclines like tigecycline have fewer renal side effects.

Antibiotics causing acute kidney injury are as follows:

  • Acute tubular necrosis:
    • Amphotericin B
    • Vancomycin
    • Acyclovir
    • Foscarnet
    • Tenofovir 
  • Acute interstitial nephritis:
    • Penicillin
    • Cephalosporins
    • Quinolones
    • Rifampicin
